core:description.@value:
REST API for API Components CI pipeline.

The `/tests` endpoint allows to schedule tests of API components and to retreive the results.

The `/user` endpoint allows to create or list API tokens.

The `/github` route is reserved for GitHub web hooks. Do not use it as it requires valid signature in the headers list generated from secret stored in GitHub.

Finally the `/groups` and `/components` endpoints allows to list or query for groups, components, and versions. This endpoints are used by the catalog.

To learn more about authorization see `Authorization` documentation page.

For suggestions about this API, please, email arc@mulesoft.com.

# Changelog

The build process for a component includes generating a changelog and storing it in 1) the `CHANGELOG.md` file of the component and 2) inserting changelog data to the datastore. This information can be retreived using this API.

## Using changelog API

### Web app

Go to [change log status page](https://ci.advancedrestclient.com/#/changelog) and provide date range for your query. The date range limits the list of results to a components released in this time period.

Note, the CI app was created in December, 2018. Components released before that may not be available.

It is possible to add tags to the query to limit the list of results to specific group of components.

Tags can be (but not limited to):
-   `apic` - The component is used in API console
-   `arc` - The component is used in Advanced REST Client
-   `amf` - The component uses AMF data model.

### REST API

Make a request to `https://api.advancedrestclient.com/v1/components/versions` endpoint.

Add `skip-docs=true` query parameter to only download the changelog. Otherwise it also returns generated data model for the documentation which can be large (in tens of KB).

Add `since` and `until` request parameters which contains a timestamp to the correspoding value to limit the list of results.

Add `tags` query parameter (it is an array) to get lit of results for specific group of components.

**Example url:**

```
https://api.advancedrestclient.com/v1/components/versions?skip-docs=true&since=1514793600000&until=1543712400000&tags=apic&tags=arc
```

Lists all available tests. By default it returns first 25 tests.
Use `limit` and `nextPageToken` parameters to enable pagination.

Limit in the response list

The `nextPageToken` is a web safe encoded cursor to the next entry in the database.
It can be obtained by requesting paginated resource and used in next request to get
next page of results.

The `nextPageToken` is a web safe encoded cursor to the next entry in the database.
It can be obtained by requesting paginated resource and used in next request to get
next page of results.

Paginated response containing a single page of the result.
By default one page of the results contains 25 items. You can extend it by setting a
`limit` query parameter in your request.
When changing parameters while using the `nextPageToken` the `nextPageToken` will be ignored
and new query will be performed. Queries with `nextPageToken` should contain the same set
of parameters as the first request.
Contains a list of objects for this method.

The next page token is a web safe encoded cursor to the next entry in the database.
Use it in the next request to obtain next page of the results.

The error response when one of the parameters is invalid and can't be parsed.
Nothing can be done at this time except correcting the request to send valid data.
Indicate that the response is errored.
The error message associated with the error.

core:description.@value:
This method creates a test and schedules worker noed to execute the test.

Note, this endpoint requires Google authentication. Currently you can
interact with this method using web app only.
Error message if any.
An ID of scheduled test. Not set when error.

Custom authentication scheme to perform some operation in the API that normally
are available for the web app via session but for CI services to create
tests from the CI pipeline without having a session set on the server.

It uses JWT standard to generate and process tokens. See more in `Authorization`
documentation.
Used to send a valid Bearer token.
Used to send a valid Bearer token.

Not authorized. The token is missing in the request, may have been revoked, expired
or token scope is not sufficient.
Use different token or create new token in application web UI.
This response won't include token integrity errors. See `400` response
for more details.
Always true. Indicates that the response is errord.
If set it means the token expired. New token is required.
Human readable message describing the error.

Provided token is invalid. The server was unable to process token value
and authorization wasn't possible.
Always true. Indicates that the response is errord.
If set it means the token expired. New token is required.
Human readable message describing the error.
Returns a test.
Indicate that the response is errored.
The error message associated with the error.
A response that is errored

Removes the test.
Note, currently the test can only be deleted when its status is `queued`.

Note, this endpoint requires Google authentication. Currently you can
interact with this method using web app only.
Status returned when the test has been deleted.
Returned when `status` of the test is not `queued`.
Indicate that the response is errored.
The error message associated with the error.

This routes are reserved for GitHub web hooks.

Called when commit status changed.
The body is described in GitHub docs.

This endpoints is not to be used by anyone except for GitHub. It uses signature verification
to pass the request.

Schedules stage branch build manually.

Note, this is a last resort! This API should not be used unless nescesary.
It may be uses in cases when the CI stuck for some reason unrelated to component
build process. **It cannot be used to force component release.**

This endpoint requires `schedule-component-build` scope on generated token.
The build scheduled successfully.

If you would like to query for component data, use `/components` route

Datastore version id.

This method allows to query for components without building key path (group > component > version).
The method allows to query for component by `tags` and `group`.

When querying by tags the combination of many tags gives a list of results where the component has
all tags defined in query parameters.

### Example

```
GET /api/components?tags=apic&tags=arc HTTP/1.1
host: ci.advancedrestclient.com:443


```

A list of tags added to limit the query to.

Tags can be (but not limited to):
- `apic` - The component is used in API console
- `arc` - The component is used in Advanced REST Client
- `amf` - The component uses AMF data model.

A list of tags added to limit the query to.

Tags can be (but not limited to):
- `apic` - The component is used in API console
- `arc` - The component is used in Advanced REST Client
- `amf` - The component uses AMF data model.

When set it only queries for a component from a specific components group.
Use this property to reduce query time and resources usage.

When set it only queries for a component from a specific components group.
Use this property to reduce query time and resources usage.

A list of tags added to limit the query to.

Tags can be (but not limited to):
- `apic` - The component is used in API console
- `arc` - The component is used in Advanced REST Client
- `amf` - The component uses AMF data model.

**Note:** Tags are a copy of component tags at the time of tag creation. The tags are not updated when component's tags change.

doc:raw.@value:
# Changelog

The build process for a component includes generating a changelog and storing it in 1) the `CHANGELOG.md` file of the component and 2) inserting changelog data to the datastore. This information can be retreived using this API.

## Using changelog API

### Web app

Go to [change log status page](https://ci.advancedrestclient.com/#/changelog) and provide date range for your query. The date range limits the list of results to a components released in this time period.

Note, the CI app was created in December, 2018. Components released before that may not be available.

It is possible to add tags to the query to limit the list of results to specific group of components.

Tags can be (but not limited to):
-   `apic` - The component is used in API console
-   `arc` - The component is used in Advanced REST Client
-   `amf` - The component uses AMF data model.

### REST API

Make a request to `https://api.advancedrestclient.com/v1/components/versions` endpoint.

Add `skip-docs=true` query parameter to only download the changelog. Otherwise it also returns generated data model for the documentation which can be large (in tens of KB).

Add `since` and `until` request parameters which contains a timestamp to the correspoding value to limit the list of results.

Add `tags` query parameter (it is an array) to get lit of results for specific group of components.

**Example url:**

```
https://api.advancedrestclient.com/v1/components/versions?skip-docs=true&since=1514793600000&until=1543712400000&tags=apic&tags=arc
```

Define when the token expires. It can be a number which will be processed as a number
of seconds until the expiration date. It can also be a string representing
amount of time until expiration and time unit, e.g. `1d` (one day), `2y` (two yers)
`1M` (one month), `15m` (fifteen minutes) and so on.

If omitted the token won't expire until is manually revoked. To revoke the token
use /me/tokens/{tokenId} DELETE method.

doc:usage.@value:
This trait is to be used when the resource is paginated that is the edpoint producses
a list of resources in the response.
Every paginated response contains a `nextPageToken` property that should be used in pagination
to request for next page of the results and `items` which is a list of resources.
The `items` property is always defined, even if the response is empty. Therefore the `404`
response in this case is not possible. Clients need to handle empty responses by their own.
It is crutial that the subsequent requests contain the same set of parameters (like `limit`
or `start`) because if this values will change then the `nextPageToken` will be revalidated
and pagination will start from the first page.

True if the user belongs to MuleSoft or Salesforce organization.
This is determinned from OAuth profile response from emai.
Not to be used. Probably will be removed.
Whether or not the user accepted terms of service.
An object representing test platform user

Name of the release channel associated with the message.
It should not be set if the channel is "stable".

Note, when querying for messages using `channel` property, if you set "stable"
value it will result with messages that has `stable` as a value, and not
empty value.
Timestamp of creation time.
Datastore key.

A label to render in the button/link associated with the message.
This is required when `actionUrl` is set.
Message title. Should be as short as possible.
A list of targeted platforms. It is indexed property used to query for the data.

An URL to full message content (blog post, website, etc).
When set the `cta` property is required. If both not set the action
button/link won't be rendered.
Object structure identifier.
The message to render in the application. It should be short version of general message.

data:value.@value: New cool features comming to the application. Download beta release channel and give use early feedback.

doc:raw.@value: New cool features comming to the application. Download beta release channel and give use early feedback.

core:description.@value: ARC info message model
Datastore test id.

Type of the test. To test API components against AMF use `amf-build`.
To perform bottom up test for a component (to test if known dependencies of a component
passes test when the component change) use `bottom-up`.

Source branch of the change initializing the test.
For AMF scheduled test it is the branch agains which the test is performed.
For bottom-up tests it is branch name of changed component

Commit SHA signature. When set it will use specific commit to build the
AMF library (when `type` is "amf-build").
For API components bottom-up tests it is the commit signature of the component
to test.
Build status of the test.
Number of components that passed the test. This property is not set when test is queued.
Number of components that failed the test. This property is not set when test is queued.
Number of components included into test. This property is not set when test is queued.

Name of the component that has changed and tests are performed on other components that has this component as a dependency.
This property is required when test type is `bottom-up`.
A timestamp when the test started.
A timestamp when the test ended.
An object representing single test.

data:value.@value:
The `nextPageToken` is a web safe encoded cursor to the next entry in the database.
It can be obtained by requesting paginated resource and used in next request to get
next page of results.

Paginated response containing a single page of the result.
By default one page of the results contains 25 items. You can extend it by setting a
`limit` query parameter in your request.
When changing parameters while using the `nextPageToken` the `nextPageToken` will be ignored
and new query will be performed. Queries with `nextPageToken` should contain the same set
of parameters as the first request.
Contains a list of objects for this method.

The next page token is a web safe encoded cursor to the next entry in the database.
Use it in the next request to obtain next page of the results.

The error response when one of the parameters is invalid and can't be parsed.
Nothing can be done at this time except correcting the request to send valid data.
Indicate that the response is errored.
The error message associated with the error.
The `limit` parameter is invalid. Please, provide a number between 1 and 300.

core:description.@value:
Custom authentication scheme to perform some operation in the API that normally
are available for the web app via session but for CI services to create
tests from the CI pipeline without having a session set on the server.

It uses JWT standard to generate and process tokens. See more in `Authorization`
documentation.
Used to send a valid Bearer token.
Used to send a valid Bearer token.

Not authorized. The token is missing in the request, may have been revoked, expired
or token scope is not sufficient.
Use different token or create new token in application web UI.
This response won't include token integrity errors. See `400` response
for more details.
Always true. Indicates that the response is errord.
If set it means the token expired. New token is required.
Human readable message describing the error.

Provided token is invalid. The server was unable to process token value
and authorization wasn't possible.
Always true. Indicates that the response is errord.
If set it means the token expired. New token is required.
Human readable message describing the error.
